stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on designing a secret area within the saloon of the cowboy level. The main focus was brainstorming, designing, and blocking out a new minecart chase mission, incorporating live feedback from his chat. He also touched on technical fixes, his personal philosophies on monetization and being a creator, and his relationship with Nintendo.

development_findings.summary: When designing the end of a minecart chase, Kaze rejected ideas that would unfairly kill the player in a cutscene, showing a commitment to respecting player agency.
development_findings.quote: I hate when games do that. That's the old win the game but lose in the cutscene trick. We can't do that.

development_findings.summary: A new mission for the saloon's secret area was designed, evolving from a simple combat encounter into a dynamic minecart chase inspired by a viewer's suggestion.
The minecart chase was designed to have the player jump between three separate, moving carts on parallel tracks to maintain the game's core platforming mechanics.
development_findings.quote: I just want three minecarts that you jump between... I still want this to be Mario movement.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to monetize the project not by selling the game, but by potentially selling a physical edition of the OST, complete with a box and instruction manual.
Kaze affirmed his commitment to his custom engine, 'Orgy.ai', over LibDragon for performance reasons, but noted he occasionally shares optimization ideas with the LibDragon developer.
development_findings.quote: LibDragon performs very poorly right now, so I definitely do not want to port it to LibDragon. But there are a few LibDragon features that I might port into Orgy.ai.

development_findings.summary: Kaze struggled to find appropriate cave textures, rejecting some for clashing with the N64 aesthetic by being too high-resolution.
development_findings.quote: I feel it's too high resolution, it's just jarring. It looks like an HD texture pack.

development_findings.summary: The game will be released for free and the entire project, including the engine, will be open source.
Kaze improved his room culling system, which skips processing actors in unseen areas, resulting in a noticeable performance improvement.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a strong anti-materialistic philosophy, stating he doesn't value expensive possessions and associates the drive to own them to impress others with a notorious mass murderer.
context_findings.quote: I don't value having expensive stuff at all... I think of Elliot Rodger, the fucking incel mass murderer... That's who I see when people I see people buying expensive things.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes selling digital games is a flawed model and prefers monetization through physical merchandise or 'souvenirs' like a boxed OST, allowing the game itself to be free.
context_findings.quote: I actually think video games should not be monetized off of video game sales. I think that's a stupid concept. Because you can make free copies of your video game... I think maybe you should sell souvenirs of your video games.

context_findings.summary: Kaze claims Nintendo has taken down over 70 of his videos when they become too popular, which he perceives as deliberate sabotage of his channel's growth.
context_findings.quote: My channel would be a lot more blown up if it wasn't for Nintendo trying to sabotage me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels the weight of being a role model for his audience, finding it somewhat depressing that this responsibility prevents him from being his unfiltered self.
context_findings.quote: When you are an online creator... you kind of are also gonna be a role model for a lot of people so there is additional responsibility on you to live your life in a good way. Which is a little depressing because I want to be a little gremlin but I can't.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a deep philosophical take that he finds mortality scarier than immortality, as he believes eternal life would give all actions inherent meaning.
context_findings.quote: I actually think non-eternal life is scarier than eternal life. Because if you have eternal life then everything you do like it automatically has meaning because you're gonna be around forever. But if you're gonna die none of it is gonna matter anymore.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is critical of Game Freak, believing they have become low-effort and unoptimized, and welcomes competition like Palworld to challenge their dominance.
context_findings.quote: I support anyone who gives Game Freak a bad time. I feel like Game Freak stopped trying like 50 years ago and them having at least a little bit of competition... is a good thing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned his girlfriend Zeina's mother was in the hospital, which he described as 'fucking depressing'.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided the 3D model for the cowboy level that Kaze was importing and setting up.
Biobak suggested the cinematic ending for the minecart chase where the final platform crumbles and collapses, an idea Kaze adopted.
Biobak proposed a pun-based dialogue line ('milky way') that Kaze decided to use as an easter egg, sparking a tangent about a conspiracy theory.
biobak.quote: I don't like that fella always talking about bounties. We do things the murky way.

zeina.summary: Zeina was supposed to provide 3D models of milk bottles for the saloon scene but had not delivered them yet.

key_stories.title: Designing the Minecart Chase Mission
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed a unique mission for the saloon's secret area. After rejecting a generic combat idea, he collaborated with his chat to design a dynamic minecart chase that emphasizes Mario's platforming abilities over a simple on-rails shooter sequence.
key_stories.challenge: A new mission was needed for the saloon's secret room, but a simple combat encounter would be repetitive and uninspired.
key_stories.process: Kaze rejected a simple 'kill five guys' mission. A viewer suggested a 'Subway Surfer style' chase. Kaze then fleshed out the idea, focusing on how to keep Mario's platforming skills central. He debated how to end the chase, rejecting frustrating 'lose in a cutscene' tricks before settling on a player-triggered platform collapse.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze, with input from his viewers and Biobak, designed a dynamic minecart chase where the player jumps between three moving carts, dodges projectiles, and ends with a cinematic platform collapse, preserving the game's platforming focus.
key_stories.key_quote: I like it to still be platforming based is the thing. I don't really want to give Mario a gun.

key_stories.title: The Bounty Conspiracy Easter Egg
key_stories.summary: A dialogue suggestion from Biobak led to Kaze sharing a personal conspiracy theory about Bounty chocolate bars being a money-laundering scheme. He decided to turn the dialogue and the theory into a hidden easter egg for players to discover.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a memorable and funny easter egg in the cowboy level.
key_stories.process: Biobak suggested a dialogue line with a pun: 'We do things the milky way here.' This prompted Kaze to share his elaborate, humorous conspiracy theory that Bounty chocolate bars are a front for a money-laundering syndicate. He loved the idea and immediately planned its implementation as a secret.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided to place Biobak's punny dialogue in a hard-to-reach location on top of the giant hat structure, rewarding dedicated players with an inside joke rooted in Kaze's personal 'game factoid'.
key_stories.key_quote: No one actually likes or buys them. They are not real chocolate bars. In reality, these are being manufactured by the drug syndicate... This is a money laundering scheme.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned having over 70 of his videos taken down by Nintendo, which he describes as 'sabotage' that has hindered his channel's growth.
questions: Can you describe the first time one of your videos was taken down and how that felt?
How has this ongoing conflict with Nintendo shaped your development philosophy or your feelings about working on their IP?
Does the threat of takedowns create a sense of defiance or urgency to finish and release the project?

open_questions.context: Kaze has a strong philosophy that games should be free, and monetization should come from 'souvenirs' like a physical OST with a manual.
questions: Where does this strong conviction about game monetization come from?
Have you looked into the logistics and costs of producing a physical cartridge and manual?
What does a 'successful' launch of this souvenir look like to you, in terms of sales or community reception?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned collaborating with the LibDragon developer on optimization ideas but ultimately sticking with his own custom engine, 'Orgy.ai', for performance reasons.
questions: Can you walk us through a specific technical idea you shared with or learned from the LibDragon dev?
What are the core architectural or philosophical differences between your engine and LibDragon that give you a performance edge?
What was the moment you realized you needed to build your own engine from scratch rather than using or forking an existing one?

open_questions.topic: The Burden of Being a Creator
open_questions.context: Kaze expressed that being a public creator comes with a 'depressing' responsibility to be a role model, which conflicts with his desire to be a 'little gremlin'.
questions: Can you give an example of a time you felt you had to suppress your 'inner gremlin' for the sake of your audience?
How do you navigate the line between being your authentic self and fulfilling this perceived role model function?
Does this pressure ever affect your creative decisions in the game itself?

open_questions.context: Kaze and Biobak demonstrated a fluid collaborative process, with Kaze quickly adopting Biobak's ideas for the minecart ending and an easter egg.
questions: Can you describe your typical creative back-and-forth? How are ideas pitched and refined between you two?
Biobak, how much freedom do you have when designing the initial look and feel of a level before Kaze begins implementation?
Can you recall a time an idea was rejected? What was the discussion around it and how was that decision made?

open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentioned that his wife, Zeina, is an animator on the project and was tasked with creating some models for the saloon.
questions: Zeina, besides the milk bottles, what other animations or assets have you created for the game?
How do you two handle creative disagreements or feedback, balancing your professional collaboration with your personal relationship?
What's it like working on such a passion project together? How does it impact your life outside of development?
